channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Families Refusing to Return, ‘Naked’ Officials Are Demoted
item.description: The series of demotions represents a new phase in the Communist Party’s campaign against “naked officials,” those who have sent their families to live overseas.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: A protest outside a courthouse in Langfang, China, where a former senior official, Liu Tienan, was sentenced to life in prison for bribery this month. China's anticorruption initiatives have wide public backing.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Beijing Battles Decline in Tourism
item.description: Beijing is considering several measures to increase tourism, including extending visa-free entry to 96 hours, the government-run newspaper China Daily reported.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A section of the Great Wall of China in Mutianyu, near Beijing. The capital is reportedly considering a number of measures to reverse a decline in international tourism, including extending visa-free entry to 96 hours.

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Airstrike Hits Gaza Site
item.description: Retaliating for a rocket fired into Israel on Friday, the Israeli military said it carried out an airstrike on a Hamas site in southern Gaza early Saturday in what was its first aerial bombing in Palestinian territory since an August cease-fire that ended this summer’s 50-day Gaza war.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Cuba Thaw Lets Rest of Latin America Warm to Washington
item.description: Leaders who have consistently lambasted the United States and President Obama abruptly changed course, praising the policy shift on Cuba.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: End of Presidential Race Leaves Tunisia Divided
item.description: Four years after the Arab Spring, Tunisians vote on Sunday in a presidential runoff that will complete their transition to democracy and end a campaign that has reopened divisions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Open Source: Israeli Politician Stars in YouTube Satire Mocking Tel Aviv Liberals
item.description: In a satirical campaign video, Naftali Bennett, the hawkish leader of the Jewish Home party, plays a stereotypical Tel Aviv peacenik.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screen shot from a campaign video in which the Israeli politician Naftali Bennett plays a Tel Aviv peacenik.

item.title: Former Marine Held in Iran Protests to Tehran Officials
item.description: Amir Hekmati, in a letter to the Iranian ministers of justice and intelligence, described deteriorating conditions in prison and deplored the lack of progress in his case.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: News Analysis: Pakistan’s Old Curse
item.description: There is little doubt that the Peshawar massacre has galvanized Pakistani society. The question is whether it can become a real turning point for a society plagued by violent divisions, culture wars and the strategic prerogatives of a powerful military.
item.category: Army Public School and Degree College (Peshawar, Pakistan)
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Children wearing white burial shrouds demonstrated on Friday in Lahore, Pakistan, against an attack by Taliban militants on an army-run school in Peshawar.

item.title: Panel to Advise Against Penalty for C.I.A.’s Computer Search
item.description: A panel investigating the agency’s search of a computer network used by staff members of the Senate Intelligence Committee who were looking into the C.I.A.'s use of torture will recommend against punishing anyone, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, has enraged senators by refusing to answer questions from the Senate Intelligence Committee about who had authorized a computer intrusion.

item.title: Crucible of Cuban Zeal Redefines Revolutionary
item.description: Cárdenas, Cuba, which is home to Elián González, is a growing city of contrasts and contradictions.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cárdenas, Cuba, home to Elián González, is a growing city of contrasts and contradictions, where some still celebrate Che Guevara.

item.title: Obama Vows a Response to Cyberattack on Sony
item.description: President Obama said the U.S. would “respond proportionally” to the attack on Sony Pictures after the F.B.I. said it had extensive evidence that North Korea had organized it.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: The headquarters of Sony Pictures in Culver City, Calif. The F.B.I. said that some of the methods employed in the Sony cyberattack were similar to ones that were used by the North Koreans against South Korean banks.

item.title: Obama Defends Actions on Cuba and Promises Some Compromise With Congress
item.description: President Obama said the reopening of relations with Cuba would give the United States more sway there, and promised to “respond proportionally” to a cyberattack on Sony.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: For Russians Abroad, a Ruble Doesn’t Go as Far as It Used To
item.description: The collapse of the Russian ruble — down more than 45 percent this year — has jangled nerves in Russia, but the reverberations are being felt in tourist destinations across Europe.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: U.S. Tightens Crimea Embargo to Pressure Russia
item.description: President Obama signed an executive order barring new investment and trade with Crimea and freezing the property of people or businesses operating in the region or helping its leadership.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Turkey Issues Arrest Warrant for a Rival of Its President
item.description: The cleric facing arrest, Fethullah Gulen, lives in Pennsylvania but still has a broad following in Turkey that has reached into elite law enforcement, judiciary and business circles.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: The cleric Fethullah Gulen at his Pennsylvania home last March.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Korean-American Arrested
item.description: China has arrested a Korean-American aid worker working near the border with North Korea on charges of embezzlement and possession of fake invoices, his lawyer said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Colombia: A Clash Before a Truce
item.description: Colombian guerrillas killed five government soldiers in a clash on Friday, the Defense Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Sony Caved to Terror. No One Else Should.
item.description: History teaches that if you give in to intimidation once, you will not reduce it in the future; you will get more of it.
item.dc:creator: By FLEMMING ROSE
item.media:description: Movie posters for "The Interview" were on display in Los Angeles last week.

item.title: Hawkish Russian Emissary To Visit Cuba’s Leaders
item.description: Dmitri O. Rogozin, an outspoken deputy prime minister, had already panned the Washington’s supposed change of heart toward Havana as a calculated change in tactics.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Mandy Rice-Davies, Figure In Sex Scandal, Dies at 70
item.description: Ms. Rice-Davies achieved notoriety in 1963 in one of Britain’s most spectacular sex scandals, which brought down a government minister.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Mandy Rice-Davies leaving court after testifying on her relationship with Lord Astor in 1963.
